column35: ]That's my little brother man, he's only six years old[
column36: ]We waited in the blistering cold for you,[
column37: ]four hours and you just said, "No."[
column38: ]That's pretty shitty man - you're like his fuckin idol[
column39: ]He wants to be just like you man, he likes you more than I do[
column40: ]I ain't that mad though, I just don't like bein lied to[
column41: ]Remember when we met in Denver - you said if I'd write you[
column42: ]you would write back - see I'm just like you in a way[
column43: ]I never knew my father neither;[
column44: ]he used to always cheat on my mom and beat her[
column45: ]I can relate to what you're saying in your songs[
column46: ]so when I have a shitty day, I drift away and put 'em on[
column47: ]cause I don't really got shit else so that shit helps when I'm depressed[
column48: ]I even got a tattoo of your name across the chest[
column49: ]Sometimes I even cut myself to see how much it bleeds[
column50: ]It's like adrenaline, the pain is such a sudden rush for me[
column51: ]See everything you say is real, and I respect you cause you tell it[
column52: ]My girlfriend's jealous cause I talk about you 24/7[
column53: ]But she don't know you like I know you Slim, no one does[
column54: ]She don't know what it was like for people like us growin up[
column55: ]You gotta call me man, I'll be the biggest fan you'll ever lose[
column56: ]Sincerely yours, Stan -- P.S.[
column57: ]We should be together too[
column58: ]{Dido}[
column59: ]Dear Mister-I'm-Too-Good-To-Call-Or-Write-My-Fans,[
column60: ]this'll be the last package I ever send your ass[
column61: ]It's been six months and still no word - I don't deserve it?[
column62: ]I know you got my last two letters;[
column63: ]I wrote the addresses on 'em perfect[
column64: ]So this is my cassette I'm sending you, I hope you hear it[
column65: ]I'm in the car right now, I'm doing 90 on the freeway[
column66: ]Hey Slim, I drank a fifth of vodka, you dare me to drive?[
column67: ]You know the song by Phil Collins, "In the Air of the Night"[
column68: ]about that guy who coulda saved that other guy from drowning[
column69: ]but didn't, then Phil saw it all, then at a a show he found him?[
column70: ]That's kinda how this is, you coulda rescued me from drowning[
column71: ]Now it's too late - I'm on a 1000 downers now, I'm drowsy[
column72: ]and all I wanted was a lousy letter or a call[
column73: ]I hope you know I ripped +ALL+ of your pictures off the wall[
column74: ]I love you Slim, we coulda been together, think about it[
column75: ]You ruined it now, I hope you can't sleep and you dream about it[
column76: ]And when you dream I hope you can't sleep and you SCREAM about it[
column77: ]I hope your conscience EATS AT YOU and you can't BREATHE without me[
column78: ]See Slim; Shut up bitch! I'm tryin to talk![
column79: ]Hey Slim, that's my girlfriend screamin in the trunk[
column80: ]but I didn't slit her throat, I just tied her up, see I ain't like you[
column81: ]cause if she suffocates she'll suffer more, and then she'll die too[
column82: ]Well, gotta go, I'm almost at the bridge now[
column83: ]Oh shit, I forgot, how'm I supposed to send this shit out?[
column85: ]{Dido}[
column86: ]Dear Stan, I meant to write you sooner but I just been busy[
column87: ]You said your girlfriend's pregnant now, how far along is she?[
column88: ]Look, I'm really flattered you would call your daughter that[
column89: ]and here's an autograph for your brother,[
column90: ]I wrote it on the Starter cap[
column91: ]I'm sorry I didn't see you at the show, I musta missed you[
column92: ]Don't think I did that shit intentionally just to diss you[
column93: ]But what's this shit you said about you like to cut your wrists too?[
column94: ]I say that shit just clownin dogg,[
column95: ]c'mon - how fucked up is you?[
column96: ]You got some issues Stan, I think you need some counseling[
column97: ]to help your ass from bouncing off the walls when you get down some[
column98: ]And what's this shit about us meant to be together?[
column99: ]That type of shit'll make me not want us to meet each other[
column100: ]I really think you and your girlfriend need each other[
column101: ]or maybe you just need to treat her better[
column102: ]I hope you get to read this letter, I just hope it reaches you in time[
column103: ]before you hurt yourself, I think that you'll be doin just fine[
column104: ]if you relax a little, I'm glad I inspire you but Stan[
column105: ]why are you so mad? Try to understand, that I do want you as a fan[
column106: ]I just don't want you to do some crazy shit[
column107: ]I seen this one shit on the news a couple weeks ago that made me sick[
column108: ]Some dude was drunk and drove his car over a bridge[
column109: ]and had his girlfriend in the trunk, and she was pregnant with his kid[
column110: ]and in the car they found a tape, but they didn't say who it was to[
column111: ]Come to think about, his name was. it was you[
column112: ]Stan!

column1: Guts Over Fear,Feels like a close, it's coming to[
column2: ]Fuck am I gonna do?[
column3: ]It's too late to start over[
column4: ]This is the only thing I, thing I know[
column5: ]Sometimes I feel like all I ever do is[
column6: ]Find different ways to word the same, old song[
column7: ]Ever since I came along[
column8: ]From the day the song called ''Hi! My Name Is" dropped[
column9: ]Started thinking my name was fault[
column10: ]Cause anytime things went wrong[
column11: ]I was the one who they would blame it on[
column12: ]The media made me the, uh, equivalent of a modern-day Genghis Khan[
column13: ]Tried to argue it was only entertainment, dawg[
column14: ]Gangsta? Naw, courageous balls[
column15: ]Had to change my style, they said I'm way too soft[
column16: ]And I sound like AZ and Nas, out came the claws[
column17: ]And the fangs been out since then[
column18: ]But up until the instant that I've went against it[
column19: ]It was ingrained in me that I wouldn't amount to a shitstain I thought[
column20: ]No wonder I had to unlearn everything my brain was taught[
column21: ]Do I really belong in this game? I pondered[
column22: ]I just wanna play my part, should I make waves or not?[
column23: ]So back and forth in my brain the tug of war wages on[
column24: ]And I don't wanna seem ungrateful or disrespect the artform I was raised upon[
column25: ]But sometimes you gotta take a loss[
column26: ]And have people rub it in your face before you get made pissed off[
column27: ]And keep pluggin', it's your only outlet[
column28: ]And your only outfit so you know they gonna talk about it[
column29: ]Better find a way to counter it quick and make it, ah[
column30: ]Feel like I've already said this a kabillion eighty times[
column31: ]How many times can I say the same thing different ways that rhyme?[
column32: ]What I really wanna say is, if there's anyone else that can relate to my story[
column33: ]Bet you feel the same way I felt when I was in the same place you are[
column34: ]When I was afraid to...[
column35: ]I was a...[
column36: ]Afraid to make a single sound[
column37: ]Afraid I would never find a way out, out, out[
column38: ]Afraid I'd never be found[
column39: ]I didn't wanna go another round[
column40: ]An angry man's power will shut you up[
column41: ]Trip wires fill this house with tip-toe love[
column42: ]Run out of excuses with every word[
column43: ]So here I am and I will not run[
column44: ]Guts over fear, the time is here[
column45: ]Guts over fear, I shall not tear[
column46: ]For all the times I let you push me around[
column47: ]And let you keep me down[
column48: ]Now I got, guts over fear, guts over fear[
column49: ]Feels like a close, it's coming to[
column50: ]Fuck am I gonna do?[
column51: ]It's too late to start over[
column52: ]This is the only thing I, thing I know[
column53: ]It's like I was there once, single parents[
column54: ]Hate your appearance, did you struggle to find your place in this world?[
column55: ]And the pain spawns all the anger on[
column56: ]But it wasn't until I put the pain in songs learned who to aim it on[
column57: ]That I made a spark, started to spit hard as shit[
column58: ]Learned how to harness it while the reins were off[
column59: ]And there was a lot of bizarre shit, but the crazy part[
column60: ]Was soon as I stopped saying "I gave a fuck"[
column61: ]Haters started to appreciate my art[
column62: ]And it just breaks my heart to look at all the pain I've caused[
column63: ]But what am I gonna do when the rage is gone?[
column64: ]And the lights go out in that trailer park?[
column65: ]And the window is closing and there's nowhere else that I can go with flows[
column66: ]And I'm frozen cause there's no more emotion for me to pull from[
column67: ]Just a bunch of playful songs that I made for fun[
column68: ]So to the break of dawn here I go recycling the same, old song[
column69: ]But I'd rather make "Not Afraid 2" than make another mothafuckin' "We Made You" uh[

column71: ]My demise and my uprise, pray to God[
column72: ]I just opened enough eyes later on[

column75: ]Cause I can't explain to y'all how dang exhausted my legs felt[
column76: ]Just having to balance my dang self[
column77: ]But on eggshells I was made to walk[
column78: ]But thank you, ma, 'cause that gave me the[
column79: ]Strength to cause Shady-mania, so many empty that stadium[
column80: ]At least I made it out of that house and a found a place in this world when the day was done[
column81: ]So this is for every kid who all's they ever did was dreamt of one day just getting accepted[
column82: ]I represent him or her, anyone similar, you are the reason that I made this song[
column83: ]And everything you're scared to say don't be afraid to say no more[

column1: Hailie's Song,Yo, I can't sing but[
column2: ]I feel like singing[
column3: ]I wanna fuckin' sing[
column4: ]'Cause I'm happy[
column5: ]Yeah, I'm happy[
column6: ]I got my baby back[
column7: ]Yo, check it out[
column8: ]Somedays I sit staring out the window[
column9: ]Watchin' this world pass me by[
column10: ]Sometimes I think there's nothin' to live for[
column11: ]I almost break down and cry[
column12: ]Sometimes I think I'm crazy[
column13: ]I'm crazy, oh, so crazy[
column14: ]Why am I here?[
column15: ]Am I just wasting my time?[
column16: ]But then I see my baby, suddenly I'm not crazy[
column17: ]It all makes sense when I look into her eyes, oh, no[
column18: ]Sometimes it feels like the world's on my shoulders[
column19: ]Everyone's leaning on me[
column20: ]'Cause sometimes it feels like the world's almost over[
column21: ]But then she comes back to me[
column22: ]My baby girl keeps gettin' older[
column23: ]I watch her grow up with pride[
column24: ]People make jokes 'cause they don't understand me[
column25: ]They just don't see my real side[
column26: ]I act like shit don't faze me, inside it drives me crazy[
column27: ]My insecurities could eat me alive[
column28: ]But then I see my baby, suddenly I'm not crazy[
column29: ]It all makes sense when I look into her eyes, oh, no[
column30: ]'Cause sometimes it feels like the world's on my shoulders[
column31: ]Everyone's leaning on me[
column32: ]'Cause sometimes it feels like the world's almost over[
column33: ]But then she comes back to me[
column34: ]Man, if I could sing, I'd keep singin' this song to my daughter[
column35: ]If I could hit the notes, I'd blow something as long as my father[
column36: ]To show her how I feel about her, how proud I am that I got her[
column37: ]God, I'm a daddy, I'm so glad that her mom didn't (want her)[
column38: ]Now you probably get this picture from my public persona[
column39: ]That I'm a pistol packin' drug addict, who bags on his mama[
column40: ]But I wanna to just take this time out to be perfectly honest[
column41: ]'Cause there's a lot of shit I keep bottled, that hurts deep inside[
column42: ]Of my soul and just know that I grow colder the older I grow[
column43: ]This boulder on my shoulder gets heavy and harder to hold[
column44: ]And this load is like the weight of the world[
column45: ]And I think my neck is breakin'[
column46: ]Should I just give up or try to live up to these expectations?[
column47: ]Now look, I love my daughter more than life in itself[
column48: ]But I got a wife that's determined to make my life livin' hell[
column49: ]But I handle it well, given the circumstances I'm dealt[
column50: ]So many chances, man, it's too bad, could have had someone else[
column51: ]But the years that I've wasted is nothing to the tears that I've tasted[
column52: ]So here's what I'm facin', three felonies, six years of probation[
column53: ]I've went to jail for this woman, I've been to bat for this woman[
column54: ]I've taken bats to people's backs, bent over backwards for this woman[
column55: ]Man, I should have seen it coming, what I stick my penis up in?[
column56: ]Wouldn't have ripped the pre-nup up if I'da seen what she was fuckin'?[
column57: ]But fuck it, it is over, there's no more reason to cry no more[
column58: ]I got my baby, baby, the only lady that I adore, Hailie[
column59: ]So sayonara, try tommorra, nice to know ya[
column60: ]Our baby's traveled back to the arms of her rightful owner[
column61: ]And suddenly it seems like my shoulder blades have just shifted[
column62: ]It's like the greatest gift you can get, the weight has been lifted[
column63: ]And now it don't feel like the world's on my shoulders[
column64: ]Everyone's leaning on me[

column66: ]Nothing can take her from me[

column74: ]Baby, I love you

column12: ]Dear Slim, I wrote but you still ain't callin[
column13: ]I left my cell, my pager, and my home phone at the bottom[

column15: ]There probably was a problem at the post office or somethin[
column16: ]Sometimes I scribble addresses too sloppy when I jot 'em[
column17: ]but anyways; fuck it, what's been up? Man how's your daughter?[

column21: ]I read about your Uncle Ronnie too I'm sorry[
column22: ]I had a friend kill himself over some bitch who didn't want him[

column24: ]I even got the underground shit that you did with Skam[
column25: ]I got a room full of your posters and your pictures man[

column31: ]Dear Slim, you still ain't called or wrote, I hope you have a chance[
column32: ]I ain't mad - I just think it's FUCKED UP you don't answer fans[
column33: ]If you didn't wanna talk to me outside your concert[
column34: ]you didn't have to, but you coulda signed an autograph for Matthew[
column35: ]That's my little brother man, he's only six years old[
column36: ]We waited in the blistering cold for you,[
column37: ]four hours and you just said, "No."[
column38: ]That's pretty shitty man - you're like his fuckin idol[
column39: ]He wants to be just like you man, he likes you more than I do[
column40: ]I ain't that mad though, I just don't like bein lied to[
column41: ]Remember when we met in Denver - you said if I'd write you[
column42: ]you would write back - see I'm just like you in a way[
column43: ]I never knew my father neither;[
column44: ]he used to always cheat on my mom and beat her[
column45: ]I can relate to what you're saying in your songs[
column46: ]so when I have a shitty day, I drift away and put 'em on[
column47: ]cause I don't really got shit else so that shit helps when I'm depressed[
column48: ]I even got a tattoo of your name across the chest[
column49: ]Sometimes I even cut myself to see how much it bleeds[
column50: ]It's like adrenaline, the pain is such a sudden rush for me[
column51: ]See everything you say is real, and I respect you cause you tell it[
column52: ]My girlfriend's jealous cause I talk about you 24/7[
column53: ]But she don't know you like I know you Slim, no one does[
column54: ]She don't know what it was like for people like us growin up[
column55: ]You gotta call me man, I'll be the biggest fan you'll ever lose[
column56: ]Sincerely yours, Stan -- P.S.[
column57: ]We should be together too[
column58: ]{Dido}[

column1: Kings Never Die,Here to stay[
column2: ]Even when I'm gone[
column3: ]When I close my eyes[
column4: ]Through the passage of time[
column5: ]Kings never die[
column6: ]I can hear the drummer drumming[
column7: ]And the trumpets, someone's tryna summon someone, I know somethin's coming[
column8: ]But I'm runnin' from it to be standing at the summit[
column9: ]And plummet, how come it wasn't what I thought it was[
column10: ]Was it, too good to be true?[
column11: ]Have nothin', get it all but too much of it[
column12: ]Then lose it again, did I swallow hallucinogens[
column13: ]Cause if not, where the hell did it go?[
column14: ]Cause here I sit in Lucifer's den by the dutch oven[
column15: ]Just choosing to sin[
column16: ]Even if it means I'm sellin' my soul, just to be the undisputed again[
column17: ]Do whatever I gotta do just to win[
column18: ]Cause I got this motherfuckin' cloud over my head[
column19: ]Crown around it, thorns on it[
column20: ]Cracks in it, bet you morons didn't think I'd be back, did ya?[
column21: ]How 'bout that, I'm somehow now back to the underdog[
column22: ]But no matter how loud that I bark, this sport is somethin' I never bow-out at[
column23: ]I complain about the game, I shout and I pout, it's a love-hate[
column24: ]But I found out that I can move a mountain of doubt[
column25: ]Even when you bitches are countin' me out, and I appear to be down for the count[
column26: ]Only time I ever been out and about[
column27: ]Is drivin' around town with my fuckin' whereabouts in a doubt[
column28: ]Cause I been lost tryna think of what I did to get here but I'm not a quitter[
column29: ]Gotta get up, give it all I got or give up[
column30: ]Spit on, shit on, stepped on, but kept goin'[
column31: ]I'm tryna be headstrong but it feels like I slept on my neck wrong[
column32: ]Cause you're moving onto the next, but is the respect gone?[
column33: ]Cause someone told me that[
column34: ](Kings never die)[
column35: ]Don't give me that sob story liar, don't preach to the choir[
column36: ]You ain't never even had to reach in the fire to dig deep[
column37: ]Nobody ever handed me shit in life, not even a flyer[
column38: ]Wouldn't even take shit into consideration[
column39: ]Obliterate anyone in the way[
column40: ]I think I see why a lot of rappers get on these features and try to show out on a track with me[
column41: ]But it'd actually have to be a fuckin' blow-out to get me to re-tire[
column42: ]Tell these new artists that kings never die[
column43: ]Did it just say I've been upstaged?[
column44: ]Why am I online? It's driving me crazy[
column45: ]I'm ridin' shotgun tryna get a gauge[
column46: ]On what's hot, but I'm not one to conform[
column47: ]But as days pass in this shit[
column48: ]And opinions sway, I can hear 'em say[
column49: ]If I stay passionate maybe I can stage a miraculous[
column50: ]Comeback as if I went away[
column51: ]But detractors just say so much for the Renegade[
column52: ]Someone's gonna make me blow my composure[
column53: ]Here I go again, center stage and I feel like I'm in a cage[
column54: ]They so want a champion to fall[
column55: ]It's no wonder why I laugh at 'em, cause why can't we win 'em all?[
column56: ]So fuck what these cynics say[
column57: ](It) just goes ta show that when my back's against the wall[
column58: ]And I'm under a tack again, that I'll act as if I'm 'posed ta[
column59: ]With this pent up rage, cause all these plaques in my office[
column60: ]On the floor stacked against the door[
column61: ]Are they just metaphors for the odds of me comin' back again?[
column62: ]Cause all the accomplishments, accolades, awards[
column63: ]And trophies just don't mean jack anymore[
column64: ]If I'm here today and gone tomorrow[
column65: ]And I'm not gonna be[
column66: ]Here to stay[
column67: ]Even when I'm gone[
column68: ]When I close my eyes[
column69: ]Through the passage of time[
column70: ]Kings never die[
column71: ]I want it, I'm comin' to get it[
column72: ]So you son of a bitches don't duck you're gonna get Riddick Bowe'd[
column73: ]Critics'll end up in critical, think your shit is dope all you're gonna get is smoked[

column76: ]Tossed in the air by my own arm, and launched so hard it broke my collarbone[

column86: ]They'll be over[
column87: ]Tryna secure your legacy like Shakur[

column89: ]So before you're leavin' this Earth[

column1: Letter To Detroit,Detroit[
column2: ]There is a resilience that rises from somewhere deep within your streets[
column3: ]You can't define it, but you can feel it[
column4: ]You can feel it overflowing from the people who call you home[
column5: ]From people who are always proud to declare, 'I'm from Detroit'[
column6: ]You took our country from it's infancy, into industry[
column7: ]And your name still carries with it the idea of a nation built on steel, muscle and sweat[
column8: ]You became the city that carried the country[
column9: ]The city, like the sport, is built on dreams[
column10: ]People who would drive to you, driven to excel[
column11: ]Who know nothing is accomplished without hardwork, without sacrifice[
column12: ]When you hurt, we hurt[
column13: ]Your streets witness our struggle[
column14: ]Your bricks are our rage through the emptiness of each house shuttered, of each factory closed[
column15: ]We've lived through the ups and the downs[
column16: ]But we remain, Detroit[
column17: ]We can never turn our backs on you Detroit, because we are you[
column18: ]My home[
column19: ]The home of Motown, Cadillac and Joe Louis[
column20: ]Through all this, we cannot be defeated, because we have never been defeated[
column21: ]You've built us, you've moved us, you've shaped us[
column22: ]Sometimes down, but never out[
column23: ]Take strength in us, your people[
column24: ]Stay up Detroit.

column2: ]Left right left, we all fall down[
column3: ]Step by step, heart to heart, left right left[
column4: ]We all fall down like toy soldiers[

column7: ]I'm supposed to be the soldier who never blows his composure[
column8: ]Even though I hold the weight of the whole world on my shoulders[
column9: ]I am never supposed to show it, my crew ain't supposed to know it[
column10: ]Even if it means goin' toe to toe with a Benzino it don't matter[
column11: ]I'd never drag them in battles that I can handle unless[
column12: ]I absolutely have to I'm supposed to set an example[
column13: ]I need to be the leader, my crew looks for me to guide 'em[
column14: ]If some shit ever just pop off, I'm supposed to be beside 'em[
column15: ]That Ja crap I tried to squash it, it was too late to stop it[
column16: ]There's a certain line you just don't cross and he crossed it[
column17: ]I heard him say Hailie's name on a song and I just lost it[
column18: ]It was crazy, this shit went way beyond some Jay-Z and nas shit[
column19: ]And even though the battle was won, I feel like we lost it[
column20: ]I spent too much energy on it, honestly I'm exhausted[
column21: ]And I'm so caught in it I almost feel I'm the one who caused it[
column22: ]This ain't what I'm in hip-hop for, it's not why I got in it[
column23: ]That was never my object for someone to get killed[
column24: ]Why would I wanna destroy something I help build[
column25: ]It wasn't my intentions, my intentions was good[
column26: ]I went through my whole career without ever mentionin'[
column27: ]Now it's just out of respect for not runnin' my mouth[
column28: ]And talkin' about something that I knew nothing about[
column29: ]Plus Dre told me stay out, this just wasn't my beef[
column30: ]So I did, I just fell back, watched and gritted my teeth[
column31: ]While he's all over TV yeah I'm talkin' a man who literally saved my life[
column32: ]Like fuck it I understand this is business[
column33: ]And this shit just isn't none of my business[
column34: ]But still knowin' this shit could pop off at any minute 'cause[
column35: ]Step by step, heart to heart, left right left[
column36: ]We all fall down like toy soldiers[
column37: ]Bit by bit, torn apart, we never win[
column38: ]But the battle wages on for toy soldiers[
column39: ]There used to be a time when you could just say a rhyme[
column40: ]And wouldn't have to worry about one of your people dyin'[
column41: ]But now it's elevated 'cuz once you put someone's kids in it[
column42: ]The shlit gets escalated, it ain't just words no more is it?[
column43: ]It's a different ball game, callin' names and you ain't just rappin'[
column44: ]We actually tried to stop the 50 and Ja beef from happenin'[
column45: ]Me and Dre had sat with him, kicked it and had a chat with him[
column46: ]And asked him not to start it he wasn't gonna go after him[
column47: ]Until Ja started yappin' in magazines how we stabbed him[
column48: ]fuck it 50 smash 'em, mash 'em and let him have it[
column49: ]Mean while my attention is pullin' in another direction[
column50: ]Some receptionist at the source who answers phones at his desk[
column51: ]Has an erection for me and thinks that I'll be his resurrection[
column52: ]Tries to blow the dust off his mic and make a new record[
column53: ]But now he's fucked the game up 'cuz one of the ways I came up[
column54: ]Was through that publication the same one that made me famous[
column55: ]Now the owner of it has got a grudge against me for nothin'[
column56: ]Well fuck it, that mother fucker can get it too, fuck him then[
column57: ]But I'm so busy being pissed off I don't stop to think[
column58: ]That we just inherited 50's beef with murder inc[
column59: ]And he's inherited mine which is fine ain't like either of us mind[
column60: ]We still have soldiers that's on the front line[
column61: ]That's willing to die for us as soon as we give the orders[
column62: ]Never to extort us, strictly to show they support us[
column63: ]We'll maybe shout 'em out in a rap or up in a[
column64: ]To show them we love 'em back and let 'em know how important it is[
column65: ]To have runyon avenue soldiers up in our corners[
column66: ]Their loyalty to us is worth more than any award is[
column67: ]But I ain't try'na have none of my people hurt or murdered[
column68: ]It ain't worth it, I can't think of a perfecter way to word it[
column69: ]Then to just say that I love y'all too much to see the verdict[
column70: ]I'll walk away from it all before I let it go any further[
column71: ]But don't get it twisted, it's not a plea that I'm coppin'[
column72: ]I'm just willin' to be the bigger man if y'all can quit poppin'[
column73: ]Off at your jaws well then I can 'cuz frankly I'm sick of talkin'[
column74: ]I'm not gonna let someone else's coffin rest on my conscience 'cuz[
column75: ]Step by step, heart to heart, left right left[
column76: ]We all fall down like toy soldiers[
column77: ]Bit by bit, torn apart, we never win[

See I don't even think you realize you playin with motherfuckers lives. I don't watch Greg get fucked on the chronic probably cause i was on it. (chorus 2x ) sometimes things just never go my way you know i, im just feelin like a pooh butt today. now every snigle day i make habits to get up but today i just feel like a pooh butt so ill stay in bed i dont know whats wrong with me im just taking everything nonchilantely i just feel like i cant move one muscle my girlfriend calls me up and tells me now we gotta hustle my plane leaves to roll about quarter to 8 its 7:15 looks like im gonna be late aww forget that baby said i just cant make it i know your dissapointed but your gonna have to take it im sick in bed im making am am foot it but before hung up the phone she told me where i could put it, comes next day i gotta call from M&M; he said we gotta make a record get ya butt outta bed i said i aint doin nothing i wish you nothing but luck he said STOP! instead of feeling like a pooh but... column1: The Night Before Christmas,Hey, Dave, 'twas the night before Christmas we'll go![
column2: ]Hi, boys, here I go![
column3: ]'Twas the night before Christmas, when all through the house[
column4: ]Not a creature was stirring, not even a mouse;[
column5: ]The stockings were hung by the chimney with care,[
column6: ]In hopes that St. Nicholas soon would be there;[
column7: ]One, two, three, four, no, Dave, don't we wanna hear some more![
column8: ]The children were nestled all snug in their beds,[
column9: ]While visions of sugar-plums danced in their heads;[
column10: ]And mamma in her 'kerchief, and I in my cap,[
column11: ]Had settled our heads for a long winter's nap,[
column12: ]When out on the lawn there a rose such a clatter,[
column13: ]I sprang from my bed to see what was the matter.[
column14: ]Away to the window I flew like a flash,[
column15: ]Tore open the shutters and threw up the sash.[
column16: ]The moon outside was shining on the snow[
column17: ]When the look will right on the ground below,[
column18: ]When, what to my wondering eyes should appear,[
column19: ]But a miniature sleigh, and eight tiny reindeer,[
column20: ]With a little old driver, so lively and quick,[
column21: ]I knew in a moment it must be St. Nick.[
column22: ]More faster than eagles the reindeer came,[
column23: ]And he whistled, and shouted, and called them by name;[
column24: ]"Now, Dasher! Now, Dancer! Now, Prancer and Vixen![
column25: ]On, Comet! On Cupid! On, Donder and Blitzen![
column26: ]To the top of the porch! to the top of the wall![
column27: ]Now dash away! dash away! dash away all!"[
column28: ]And then, in a twinkling, I heard on the roof[
column29: ]The prancing and pawing of each little hoof.[
column30: ]As I drew in my hand, and was turning around,[
column31: ]Down the chimney St. Nicholas came with a bound.[
column32: ]He was dressed all in fur, from his head to his foot,[
column33: ]And his clothes were all tarnished with ashes and soot;[
column34: ]A bundle of toys he had flung on his back,[
column35: ]And he looked like a peddler just opening his pack.[
column36: ]His eyes -- how they twinkled! his dimples how merry![
column37: ]His cheeks were like roses, his nose like a cherry![
column38: ]His cute little mouth was just like a bow,[
column39: ]And the beard of his chin was as white as the snow;[
column40: ]He had a broad face and a little round belly,[
column41: ]That shook, like a bowlful of jelly.[
column42: ]He was chubby and plump, a right jolly old elf,[
column43: ]And I laughed when I saw him, in spite of myself;[
column44: ]A wink of his eye and a twist of his head,[
column45: ]Soon gave me to know I had nothing to dread;[
column46: ]He spoke not a word, but went straight to his work,[
column47: ]And filled all the stockings; then turned with a jerk,[
column48: ]And laying his finger aside of his nose,[
column49: ]And giving a nod, up the chimney he rose;[
column50: ]He sprang to his sleigh, to his team gave a whistle,[
column51: ]And away they all flew like the down of a thistle.[
column52: ]But I heard him exclaim, ere he drove out of sight,[
column53: ]"Merry Christmas to all, and good-night."

column85: ]Homie I'll never forget you, no

column1: Youre Never Over,

Zane Lowe BBC Radio Interview Part 1,Zane Lowe: Welcome back to Radio One, Maida Vale studio 4 here we are. Part of the reason we're here obviously because its the BBC but also because we have Studio 3 around the corner and you've got the band set up and going to perform some songs as well.[
column2: ]Eminem: It's super exciting to be here. I was trying to figure out how I was going to top the publicity of yours and Kanye's interview so I decided I was going to walk in here, pee on the floor, and leave. I'm peeing right now. Alright see you guys later![
column3: ]ZL: Seeing you with the band, and seeing you perform the other night at the awards show and seeing you on the mic, it was, I don't think I've ever seen you more alive on the mic. It was full of energy and in the moment. What I noticed was as well was spitting live with the band behind you seemed to free you up a lot more. Are you feeling that way?[
column4: ]E: I think performing has gotten a lot different, it's gotten better with the band because there's just more elements to it and being it is a live show, there's more places you can go with it. There's things you can do with your hands, it's really cool, it's different. I think it's better.[
column5: ]ZL: Spitting Rap God that just puts everything into perspective I think for everybody else. When you wrote that and you got that one down and recorded it...[
column6: ]E: I didn't write that, I freestyled it, off the dome, 1 take.[
column7: ]ZL: Absolutely ridiculous. The song is ridiculous it doesn't make any sense whatsoever.[
column8: ]E: Thank you[
column9: ]ZL: When you get to perform that live that must be, I saw at the end once you finished that, that's a challenge for anybody. At the end you must feel like 'Wow'. That's a lot of rhymes to get through, it's like 5 or 6 minutes non-stop.[
column10: ]E: Um, Yeah the other night I don't think we did the whole song. We did kind of a Deadly Medley.[
column11: ]ZL: I don't even know how you would cut that up and make a shorter version of that because it's such a stream of consciousness through the whole track.[
column12: ]E: Yeah I don't know. I wouldn't even want to begin to think of that, because I think it is a... stream of consciousness. Nice stream of consciousness, running down my leg.[
column13: ]ZL: The album itself has been so well received by everyone including fans across the world. Because in my opinion listening to it now it's kinda the perfect combination of the venom and the danger that existed on the 1st record but also what you've been through and what you've learnt over the past 5 or 6 years. It's kind of like the combination of the two. Is that fair do you think? The first album that feels like it's slightly grown up, but also going back to some of those subject matters and dealing with that stuff.[
column14: ]E: It's grown up and down. I mean some of the themes and topics and things like that are revisited on this album, but at the same time I feel like its kind of a 2013 version. All my albums I think, for the most part, pretty much tell where I'm at, you know at each one at that time period, whatever. So this is kinda like, there's a lot of reflecting and things like that back on everything that was happening during that time, you know. And it's kinda like me reflecting on it and getting to the point where I am now with it.[
column15: ]ZL: Settling some scores as well, and burying the hatchets and dealing with stuff once and for all. Do you feel like this album has allowed you to do that?[
column16: ]E: I mean some stuff, yeah. But for the most part I just felt like it might be fun to just revisit that, the overall vibe of that album. Just because it started to go there in the recording process.[
column17: ]ZL: So when did that begin like you were going down that road?[
column18: ]E: I had started making a few records for it, and it just sounded like the tonality of it, the tones of the records kinda were heading towards that way. And I figured out what direction it should go in, kinda started gearing everything that way. And alotta times, making an album, I dont always have the direction or concept early on. Sometimes it doesn't come until the middle/towards the end of a record to figure out where I'm actually going with that... that's just a culmination of songs, and depending on what the vibe is. Sometimes I do a songs that is so left field one or two of them its like Oh Shit where am I going to put these songs and now what am I going to call it because its not going to make sense to go, let's say Recovery or whatever. But with this one I feel like I kinda got an earlier idea for a concept.[
column19: ]ZL: That must be nice actually to be able to sit down and carve it out as it was going and have that end result in mind, to piece it together that way.[
column20: ]E: It was, but it wasn't, in the sense of-- I had to record a lot of songs for it because I felt like if I'm going to call it that, I want it to make sense.[
column21: ]ZL: And the stakes are high as well. I was talking to someone about this before and they were saying, "Eminem would never consider one of his albums to be a classic" he's not that way inclined. But you know how people feel about the Marshall Mathers LP, it speaks volumes. And then the critics, every layer of it, it is considered a modern day classic album. Did you consider the expectation of calling it that and what it would mean to the record overall?[
column22: ]E: Yeah, I had kinda known that going in. Once I kinda new what direction I was going, I knew that I needed certain songs to be able to call it that, and like I said to be able to make sense. But, I just wanted to make sure that I had the right ones, and in other words, I knew that, obviously Stan off the first Mathers LP was a big topic. And I had heard a lot of chatter around the time doing the Recovery record that I should do Stan 2 and why doesn't he do Stan 2, and all I kept thinking was Stan's dead. You know what I'm saying, he died in the story. So in the back of my mind I kinda had an idea of who could be left from the story, but I needed to get the right beat and be able to...[
column23: ][plays song][
column24: ]ZL: As soon as it starts as well. Did you know immediately this would be the beat for this concept?[
column25: ]E: Yeah, as soon as I heard the words to the chorus... I got this beat, this beat was sent to me and had those words on it. And sometimes for me it's like- I like making my own choruses and its also fun for me to take someone else's words and interpret them my own way.[
column26: ]ZL: For sure, when you hear that chorus I'm sure initially... it's a 1st person scenario or self hatred scenario, but its tied into- there's layers to that. Being bad is good I hate to be it but here I am and I'm back again. And then you got to deal with the story, and at the end it's taking everyone to the end when you couldn't be facing down any more of the criticism both self and by others that you faced throughout your career. I mean it's the ultimate type of acknowledgement isn't it?[
column27: ]Meeting your maker almost really, is that the inspiration behind it?[
column28: ]E: It's kinda like saying, if you're going to go down this road, then you're going to call it this, and this is going to be the title, and this is all of these things coming back on me.[
column29: ]ZL: It's an amazing opening to the record and it's really ambitious as well. So you set the bar really really high and from here we go to Rhyme or Reason, and I love that beat and love the big samples and first time you reference Rick Rubin as a producer on the record. When did you first have the idea of working with Rick?[
column30: ]E: I've always been a fan of Rick's, and my manager Paul had been talking to him and Rick had expressed that he had interest in working with me. And when Paul brought it to my attention I was like super excited, honored at the fact that he was even thinking about it. I had my reservations just because I felt like I'm a super fan of Rick, and I'd probably be a little nervous and wouldn't know what the vibe would be because I would be wanting to impress him. It was very much the feeling that I got early on with Dre.[
column31: ]ZL: Had you met Rick before?[
column32: ]E: Nah, I'd never met him. So I was like nervous to meet him and you know, even more nervous to work with him.[
column33: ]ZL: Same thing with Dre, all the way back, same kind of experience when you walked in the studio and saw Dre that time..[
column34: ]E: Yeah I'm still always trying to impress Dre too to this day at the same time. But I just kept thinking if I got in the studio with Rick, what if we're not able to come up with anything. I had all these things in my head, and then when I met him, the guy's so laid back, it made it easy. And his vibe in the studio is very much like... "Try whatever", don't be afraid to try whatever, even if the idea in the beginning is stupid. Because a lot of ideas in the beginning stages, not mine of course, mine are just insane from the moment I think of them- but sometimes ideas are not always the greatest.[
column35: ]ZL: Don't be afraid to fail to get somewhere else, to get on the journey.[
column36: ]E: So if you say one thing that's going to spark another thing to lead to a better thought, that's kinda how it went. We started going through old break beats and I was trying to tell him I kinda had the idea, I kinda had a notion that I was going to call it the Marshall Mathers LP 2, but I didn't want to say anything yet to him because I wasn't 100 percent sure- and I wanted to make sure that I had enough songs to even play for him that would make sense. I love the sound that Rick gets when he does hip hop. Even from early on, Beastie Boys- it's incredible. And that's what I was kinda hoping to get.[
column37: ]How can I make the record sound nostalgic, but subliminally nostalgic. So it reminded you of maybe 13 years ago when you first heard me but its overs beats that are even older, but you're not sure why you feel this way. Tried to create a feel, so we started messing with old samples and break beats and things like that- cuz Rick is super talented and mastered of every other genre of music as well. The way he dips in and out of just different genres is crazy to me. Like I said, I was hoping to get what I got from him.[
column38: ]ZL: The first time I saw Berzerk as well, I was so happy to see the way that you came through, and the video the way the colors were so reverse Beastie Boy style- it was fan boy stuff for me. To be able to go out in a beanie like the Ad-Rock thing and it was cool, I love that.

column1: Zane Lowe BBC Radio Interview Part 2,[Snippet from "Brainless"][
column2: ]"Who can say for sure? Perhaps a frontal lobotomy would be the answer[
column3: ]If science could operate on this distorted brain and put it to good use[
column4: ]Society will reap a great benefit."[
column5: ][Zane Lowe][
column6: ]Let's talk about your work on the record as a producer, because I know on Relapse you did nothing, on Recovery you got back into it, I've always said to you as long as I've know you or you've been making beats how much of a fan I am of your particular music, your production for others as well as just for yourself.[
column7: ][Eminem][
column8: ]Oh, thank you.[
column9: ][Zane Lowe][
column10: ]And so to hear you back making beats again on some of the standout beats on the record was a real thrill. So, I mean, how was that getting back into the producer's chair and deciding to wear two hats again?[
column11: ][Eminem][
column12: ]Urm, I mean that was fun, it was fun to, to be able to, just mess around with beats from scratch again and, you know, sometimes, like, I think Recovery was the first time that I ever got really super-open to, urr, working with a lot of other producers, you know that was the most I had ever done, and, you know, aside from working with Dre. You know, so, on that album kind of opened those doors a little bit, so that's kinda how early on, we started approaching this record, or this album, and sometimes, like I may get something in my head like an idea or the mood of something that I would want and I'm not always gonna get that by going through, you know, different tracks if other people have made, they don't know what's in my head, you know what I'm saying, so it's also a good way to, ur, I think maybe it helps with diversity a little bit too, with the sound and all that, you know, I would get something in my head and wanna be able to lay that idea down from scratch.[
column13: ][Zane Lowe][
column14: ]It just sounds like your being inspired by rap, in a big big way, I mean...[
column15: ][Eminem][
column16: ]Absolutely[
column17: ][Zane Lowe][
column18: ]I mean, I know you've always been that way, we've known each other for a long time and I've met you at various points throughout every album and I know that it's...[
column19: ][Eminem][
column20: ]I just met you, out there I thought... It's all good man, I'm still peeling the floors. (Laughter)[
column21: ][Zane Lowe][
column22: ]Um, you know and the music reflects your head space, it's always been pretty honest, not just lyrically but also musically I mean there was a time when the beats you were making were all very kind of minor key and lots of strings and lots of, kind of, a lot of Drama. The beats on here are fun. I mean, they're fat, big and rap! Like inspired by hip-hop![
column23: ][Eminem][
column24: ]Yeah, I mean, it's pretty much all I do, and all I wanna do, you know what I'm saying like, so it's fun for me, like I'm still, you know, like I'm still passionate about hip-hop, and every aspect of it, so, making beats and producing, you know, is definitely, it's fun for me.[
column25: ][Zane Lowe][
column26: ]What is it about rap that you love? I mean I'm a huge, I mean I grew up on hip-hop and it forms pretty much every sort of thing I've ever done in my life pretty much to some form, and what I wondered, you know, being someone who is considered one of the greatest of all time, what is it about rap the art form, if you can even trace it back to when you first discovered it, to how you feel about it now and what are your most rap-heavy records?[
column27: ][Eminem][
column28: ]You know, just a lot of rap.[
column29: ][Zane Lowe][
column30: ]A lot of rapping on there, a lot of words?[
column31: ][Eminem][
column32: ]Yeah[
column33: ][Zane Lowe][
column34: ]What is it about it that you love, if you can put it into words?[
column35: ][Eminem][
column36: ]Hmm, I dunno, I, urm, I love the fact that you can, I love the expression of it. The fact that you can, you know, just, I don't know, I love the, I love beats and rhymes and I love the fact that you can express yourself in a rhyme and lay it down and it can be therapeutic, and you've got it off your chest, and then you could go on to the next thing, I don't know, there's so much shit that I love about rap, you know, I'm in it for like, I love to watch what's going on in the game and keep my finger on the pulse of that, you know, and it's exciting to watch as a fan, for me too, you know, just being a fan of hip-hop, urm, and watching as it, you know, the evolution of it, and, you know, how it moves from each year to year, you know what I'm saying, the direction, and...[
column37: ][Zane Lowe][
column38: ]Are you sort of relieved that you can be that now, you can be a contender for the world's greatest rapper along with a selection of your peers and it can be a really amazing rap record and to a certain extent, I hope you take this the right way because I know your strong career, very popular, number 1 in 80+ countries, huge, but the pop stars kind of did, you know, in the sense of what people expect from you these days, isn't it, you don't have to be that guy any more, you can just be a rapper and make rap records if you want. Is that a relief?[
column39: ][Eminem][
column40: ]Well, yeah, I think so, urm, it's one of them things like, as far as like, being a pop star or whatever like, I never, never intended to be any of that, you know wha I'm saying, like, all I ever wanted to do was get respect from, you know, my peers and other rappers, and, urm, all the other stuff that came with it was just, you know, confusing to me, it was, I don't know, like I don't feel like I ever set out to make a pop song or a song that was gonna be some kind of crossover song or whatever... is that for me?[
column41: ][Zane Lowe][
column42: ]Yeah, if you want it.[
column43: ][Eminem][
column44: ]Thanks man, appreciate it. Urm...[
column45: ][Zane Lowe][
column46: ]And then boom, you did! And it didn't stop for years![
column47: ][Eminem][
column48: ]Well boom, it happened but at the same time, like - I never wanted to - when things did did keep happening and when certain things kept hitting the radio and things like that, I mean, I don't think I'm stupid. I'm not stupid. Like, I know when a song has a certain particular sound and sounds like "well maybe this could possibly be a radio record", or when I'm going "fuck, shit, ass!" you know what I'm saying, and I know "this will never go to radio". But at the same time, if a song starts heading that way, cause a lot of times I may even think, I may even think certain things when I'm writing it, like, maybe what person this might connect with, you know what I'm saying like, and who I might connect with with this song. But I never, in making any song I have made, I never wanted to compromise lyrical integrity, yeah, you know, and I always wanted to make sure that if I was rapping on a beat that had some kind of appeal to it and was catchy, that I was at least doing my job as an MC, and you know what I'm saying...[
column49: ][Zane Lowe][
column50: ]Oh that's the struggle![
column51: ][Eminem][
column52: ]And doing what I feel like I need to do.[
column53: ][Zane Lowe][
column54: ]That's tough man, because you want to give as much quality as you possibly can through your music, you're not going to hold yourself back in case you get successful, but at the same time like you say it's never been on the agenda, and I guess in a way that was part of what caused the problem in the first place that just manifested over that time, huh, like, how do I do both? How do I be good and not court this, not be this guy that everybody expects something from?[
column55: ][Eminem][
column56: ]Yeah, urm, I know that early on I went through a lot of that with the "Hi, my name is" record, and it was, urm, like I never understood, like I understood that the record was funny, and i understood that it was a little, urm, how you say, kitschy, or whatever, and maybe the hook was, the whole record was tongue-in-cheek. You know what I'm saying, like I'm still doing a lot of records like that to this day, with the tongue-in-cheek, but that record in particular was just like, it was my, it was almost like my anti-pop song cause it was like my hello to the world but it was my "fuck you" to the world at the same time. So I never understood, like, when all that started happening, like holy shit how did that become a, you know, I guess pop song.[
column57: ][Zane Lowe][
column58: ]So when did the penny drop and you realized the more you say "fuck you", the more people are gonna say, you know, "hi, we love you"?[
column59: ][Eminem][
column60: ]Urm, I don't know, I mean...[
column61: ][Zane Lowe][
column62: ]Probably around the Marshall Mathers LP right, cause that's when it really started to, to blow up again?[
column63: ][Eminem][
column64: ]Yeah, I think, I think there was a lot of that, and I think that just, coming from being an underground MC and being an underdog and things like that kinda gave me that attitude I think, you know, I think that had a lot to do with it, and then, you know, watching NWA and other people, 2Pac, you know what I'm saying, like, it was like, he's not going to, him or they, aren't going to kiss your ass to make you like their music.[
column65: ][Zane Lowe over snippet from "Survival"][
column66: ]Yeah, that's exactly what they want to do, let things slide a bit, you know. Now, you kind of talk about that on this song here, on The Monster (plays snippet from "The Monster"), and I think this is the one where you really address it in the most eloquent way about like, it's the gift and the curse, you know, I'm aware of the trouble it can get you in, I've been through that, you know. Number 1 album, number 1 movie, number 1 this number 1 that, not really in a position to really, kind of, really, be able to absorb that, yet, it's intoxicating, isn't it?[
column67: ][Eminem][
column68: ]Yeah, it was like, it was this thing, where, and I'm not gonna lie, I still wish it today, that it was like this thing where I want this attention for this music, but then I wanna be able to go in public, and I wanna be able to eat a fucking sandwich, you know what I mean, and be left alone. So, it was like "man, if I could...", because, I'd never been an attention seeker, and it seems like a hell of a career choice, you know, but, I don't like attention, that's not just why I do it, just to get attention, I don't like to be in public and walk around and be, like, here I am, you know what I mean, like, it's not what I want, I just wanted, my dream was, my dream was for like, fuck man, to be able to one day, like hear rappers that I look up to on the radio, like "yo, what if Jay Z, whoever, what if they heard of me, what if they thought I was dope? You know what I'm saying like? That was where my mentality always was, was with it. So when it all went crazy it was really hard to wrap my head around, you know, a lot of it still is, but especially back then.[
column69: ][Zane Lowe][
column70: ]Yeah. You know, you have done something which very few people have done now, you've actually been at the center of the world, the center of that storm, and you've emerged out of it, you popped out of the other side of it, I mean. Elvis didn't do that, you know, Michael Jackson didn't do that, Whitney Houston... a lot of people who have been in the public eye to that extent, unfortunately the list of various reasons, I'm sure personal to them, is too long, who didn't make it through. You have, and what does the world look like to you, when you've come out the other side of that, and you're 5 years sober and you're looking on that chaos for some perspective?[
column71: ][Eminem][
column72: ]Urm, I don't know, I mean I'm definitely thankful, you know what I mean, I know that could have certainly took another path...[
column73: ][Zane Lowe][
column74: ]And gone that way, yeah.[
column75: ][Eminem][
column76: ]Yeah, I could have went another direction but, I don't know, I mean, I think that, I feel like, like I'm probably able to see it, I'm able to be more focused now than I've ever been, urm, but I'm also able to I guess put it in perspective. The problem is I can't put a lot of perspective because I don't, there's a lot that's, you know, gone, there's a lot that I don't remember, and maybe that's cool, too, you know what I'm saying, where...[
column77: ][Zane Lowe][
column78: ]Probably a good thing?[
column79: ][Eminem][
column80: ]Yeah but, I don't know man, I know, I know that, there's so many addicts in this world, you know, and people who have problems like that, that don't make it, you know what I'm saying so I, I'm thankful for that, but urr, you know, I think that's one thing that really helps me, urr, through, and just, keeps me pushing forward is the music, is the passion for that and, and, and, you know.
